"On men instead of bricks and
mortar" said President Gilman when
he founded the Johns Hopkins university at the alley between Howard
and Eutaw streets, "did I spend the
money that was left for the university."
That money was left by a Quaker
merchant, Johns Hopkins, who when
he died left in his will six million dollars for the founding of both a university and a hospital. The hospital,
which was an entirely different project, was founded 13 years after the
University. The two now meet
through the boards of trustees of
both organizations.
At the time that the Johns Hepkins
university was founded, 1876, there
were few graduate schools in this
country; and it is recognized by
authority that Johns Hopkins was
the first "real" graduate school.
President Gilman got about 7 fellows
together to do graduate work in research I All of these men have become
famous in their fields. Several of
them already had a Ph D degree from
a European institution.
It was on this German and English
pattern that the school was founded,
and though the trends of education
have changed, it is said, that Hopkins
still has retained, to a certain extent, the original plan.
The purpose of the European plan
was to give the students as much
freedom as possible. It intended to
provide the scholars who desired to
learn and to have those who were
idlers drift along and finally fall to
the wayside.
Adhering to the policy of freedom,
the graduate school is now considered to be one of the few schools in
America which cooperates in accordance with the European plan as set

The signature at the end of
this piece is my last official
act as editor of the NEWSLETTER. By the time it is
read, they will probably
have elected my successor.
And so I have been sitting here in the dirty office for an hour or more, trying
to think of a way to close the chapter. It doesn't seem
too easy to write formally and definitely about an association, which has been as intimate as has mine with

this paper.
I just haven't the stomach to draw up any bare
--statemzat of the highlights of my editorial career.
There is in my memory only the vision of great fights
which were never fought and sacred duties which were
never fulfilled.
As a matter of fact, the things that have made the
last four years with the NEWS-LETTER important to me
haven't much to do with editorial pronouncements
anyway. They are bound up with a thousand hours of
aimless, inexpert conversation whiCh still gives no prospect of ever coming to any conclusion. With eating
hot dogs at Al's Grill and lighting cigars at the blue
flame on the linotype. With some very drab crusades
and some very gaudy jokes. But, most of all, with the
people I have known and the way they lived and
thought and talked.
For the things I will miss are the things of the
spirit. As the world judges such matters this may or
may not be a rather lousy paper. But, it is the only
paper I know where the staff could put off reading
proof to listen to the work of a new poet. Those who
work on it may or may not be incompetents. But they
are young, and they are blessed with hope and a constitutional inability to say yes. The place in which I am
writing now may or may not be as impressive as an
up-to-date newspaper plant would be. But I'll wager
the air is a good bit cleaner.
These are my people that I am leaving.'They have
shared their best thoughts and their last cigarettes
with me. Such as it is, this is my testament to them.
—Murray Keanpton

face for our representatives. The campus is in accord

and opposed to every attempt to extend them.
In some ways this position is quite logical. There
is no conceivable reason why the council, as now
constituted, should be given direct control over all
undergraduate activities. Certainly the record of the
past offers no basis for any confidence in its use of
such a power.
But, imperfect instrument that it is, the council

body before the administration. As such, it is our only
honest hope for the establishment of some measure of
democratic control.
The proposed re-definition of powers is practical
only when it is coupled with measures designed to turn
student government back to the campus. But, even
limited .to its present functions, the Council cannot
escape the necessity of submitting to popular control.
